title: 105_hr1998
content: The Act may be cited as the "Yates Firearm Registration and Crime Prevention Act of 1997". The Congress finds that crimes committed with guns threaten the peace, security, and welfare of the nation, increase firearm-related crimes due to unregulated circulation, create a burden on commerce, and discourage travel between states. Individual state regulations are ineffective due to lax regulations in other states. The need for national legislation to establish minimum standards for firearm registration and regulation is crucial to enable effective state action. Gun crimes have disrupted national political processes and pose a threat to the republican form of government. Firearm-related deaths and injuries are disproportionately high among younger age groups and minorities, with firearm homicide being the second leading cause of death for 15- to 19-year-olds. The Second Amendment protects states' rights to organize militias in emergencies. Firearm ownership is a privilege like driving, and the government must regulate to protect the public. Government officials, including Presidents, have been assassinated with firearms, highlighting the threat posed by unregulated gun circulation. SEC. 3. REGISTRATION OF FIREARMS AND FIREARM TRANSFERS; FIREARMS PERMITS. Title 18, United States Code, amended with CHAPTER 44A for firearm registration and permits. Title 18, United States Code, amended with CHAPTER 44A for firearm registration and permits. It is unlawful for any person who owns or manufactures a firearm in the United States to fail to register the firearm with the Secretary within specified timeframes. Penalties are outlined for non-compliance. Title 18, United States Code, amended with CHAPTER 44A for firearm registration and permits. It is unlawful for any person who transfers a firearm in the United States to fail to register the transfer with the Secretary within 7 days. Registration requires submitting personal information to the Secretary. Delivery by a common carrier is exempt from this requirement. Title 18, United States Code, amended with CHAPTER 44A for firearm registration and permits. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess a firearm or ammunition without a permit issued by the Secretary. Reporting a lost or stolen firearm is mandatory within 48 hours of discovery. It is illegal to transfer or receive a firearm without a valid firearms permit issued by the Secretary. The permit must be displayed during the transaction. Exceptions apply to common carriers transporting firearms. Applicants must be at least 18 years old to apply for a firearms permit. To purchase a firearm, the individual must be at least 18 years old, not indicted or convicted of a crime punishable by over a year in prison, not a fugitive, not a drug user or addict, not mentally defective or committed to a mental institution, not an illegal alien, not dishonorably discharged from the armed forces, and not a former citizen. To purchase a firearm, the individual must meet certain criteria, including not being a former citizen who renounced their citizenship and not being subject to a court order restraining them from harassing or threatening an intimate partner or child. The applicant must provide a photograph, fingerprints, and additional personal information as required by the Secretary for firearm purchase. The applicant must provide personal information, photograph, and fingerprints as required by the Secretary for firearm purchase. The firearms permit issued will be invalid if it becomes unlawful for the person to receive a firearm in interstate or foreign commerce. It is unlawful to fail to return the permit within 7 days after it becomes invalid. The owner of an unregistered firearm may dispose of it at a designated place within a year. The Secretary may pay the owner the fair market value of a firearm upon designation. Firearms acquired by the Secretary will be destroyed, except those needed for criminal investigation or with historic/technological value. Penalties for knowingly owning, possessing, transferring, or receiving firearms in violation include fines and imprisonment up to 10 years. Obliterating a firearm's serial number or violating specific sections can result in fines and imprisonment up to 10 years or 5 years, respectively. The Secretary may establish and maintain records of firearms. Violations of firearm regulations can result in fines, imprisonment, or both. Seizure and forfeiture of firearms involved in violations are subject to the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary is responsible for maintaining records of information submitted under this chapter, cooperating with law enforcement, establishing rules and regulations, and imposing fees for firearm registration and permits. The Secretary is responsible for maintaining records, cooperating with law enforcement, and imposing fees for firearm registration. Federal agencies must assist the Secretary unless the President prohibits it. The chapter does not intend to override state laws unless there is a direct conflict. The effective date of the amendment is one year after enactment.
